title: I guess the live design team truly doesnt play the game.
body:
Meddler thinks blitzcrank is more overpowered than alistar and leona (and they dont even have nerfs planned for those 2 100% pick/ban in high elo lmao).

I haven't played an ounce of Softball, yet I've professionally Umpired for the game for over 4 years now, and even more while I was still learning. Why? Because being an Umpire is about understanding the rules of the game, being observant, and having good judgement. You play Softball to learn the mechanics of the game, not the rules. 

If I had a softball for every time I heard a kid or coach complain about a rule that they've never read, I'd have un-ordinarily large amount of softballs for someone who doesn't play the game to have. Being able to hit a ball does not impact my ability to be an Umpire, nor does it have any influence on how I call my games. Being able to slide home does not affect my ability to make a judgement about an interference. 

What matters, what truly matters, is whether or not you have an interest in the game. While I do not play Softball, I enjoy watching it. I find a great deal pleasure in Umpiring it, and to a slight degree, taking a ball to the thigh for the... *ump*-teenth time cause of some cute young kid trying to pitch for their second time. If you don't even have an interest in the game, than you will fail as an Ump, and as a designer.

That is the key difference.

I will comment that Ghostcrawler technically is correct.  You don't _need_ to play a game to design it.  You absolutely need to understand it however, and it quite often feels like the developers don't understand it.

As far as Meddler's opinion on Blitz, I would actually agree with that for the vast majority of the player base.  Keep in mind that 80% of players are not at  or above the level where Alistair and Leona are seen as a pick or ban every game.  Blitz has:

* Insane pick ability against people who aren't good at dodging skillshots.
* Reasonably high safety because he doesn't have to go in to make a pick.
* Mediocre peel.
* Mediocre survivability solo.

In contrast, Leona has:

* Good pick ability against anyone.
* Great peel.
* Very good damage for a support focused tank.
* Somewhat insane solo survivability.
* Very high risk, as she pretty much has to go in to make a pick.

And Alistair has:

* Insane pick ability against people who are severely out of position.
* Insane peel.
* Built in healing.
* Very good solo survivability.
* Reasonably high risk because he has to put himself out of position to pick targets.

In short, Blitz is a low risk, high reward character at low tier play where people can't really dodge worth crap and don't do a very good job of focusing down specific targets, but ends up being a liability at high tier play where people are good at dodging and very much tend to focus specific targets (most notably the Blitz).  Such champs end up being a serious pain in the arse for most players, and quite often terrorize alternate game modes (Seriously, Blitz is a top priority ban on Legend of the Poro King at all tiers of play because it's hard as hell to dodge reliably on such a narrow map).

In contrast, Leona and Alistair are high risk, high reward characters at all tiers who both bring a lot of utility to a team.  Champs like that are really popular at top-tier play (See Lee Sin for another example), but generally aren't a significant issue for most players regardless of what level of play they are at (provided they aren't being played by smurfs).  They tend to be banned a lot in high-level play just as much to screw up one-trick ponies as they are to avoid having to deal with them.

Note that I'm not saying Leona and Alistair aren't an issue right now (anything on the level of 100% pick/ban is an issue), just that 'fixing' Blitzcrank is going to make a lot more people happy than dealing with Leona or Alistar will.

The game should not be balanced around bad people. If you don't do that, they will eventually develop their own ways to handle it. One of Riots biggest problems is that they often nerf trends before people have really had enough time to learn to play against it, and at this point much of the playerbase expects that and rarely tries to adapt
